title: Obfuscated Files or Information
descrption: Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit. This is common behavior that can be used across different platforms and the network to evade defenses.Payloads may be compressed, archived, or encrypted in order to avoid detection. These payloads may be used during Initial Access or later to mitigate detection. Sometimes a user's action may be required to open and Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information for User Execution. The user may also be required to input a password to open a password protected compressed/encrypted file that was provided by the adversary. [1] Adversaries may also used compressed or archived scripts, such as Javascript.Portions of files can also be encoded to hide the plain-text strings that would otherwise help defenders with discovery. [2] Payloads may also be split into separate, seemingly benign files that only reveal malicious functionality when reassembled. [3]Adversaries may also obfuscate commands executed from payloads or directly via a Command-Line Interface. Environment variables, aliases, characters, and other platform/language specific semantics can be used to evade signature based detections and whitelisting mechanisms. [4] [5] [6]Another example of obfuscation is through the use of steganography, a technique of hiding messages or code in images, audio tracks, video clips, or text files. One of the first known and reported adversaries that used steganography activity surrounding Invoke-PSImage. The Duqu malware encrypted the gathered information from a victim's system and hid it into an image followed by exfiltrating the image to a C2 server. [7] By the end of 2017, an adversary group used Invoke-PSImage to hide PowerShell commands in an image file (png) and execute the code on a victim's system. In this particular case the PowerShell code downloaded another obfuscated script to gather intelligence from the victim's machine and communicate it back to the adversary. [8]
Data Sources: Network protocol analysis, Process use of network, File monitoring, Malware reverse engineering, Binary file metadata, Process command-line parameters, Environment variable, Process monitoring, Windows event logs, Network intrusion detection system, Email gateway, SSL/TLS inspection
Defense Bypassed: Host forensic analysis, Signature-based detection, Host intrusion prevention systems, Application whitelisting, Process whitelisting, Log analysis, Whitelisting by file name or path

related.Name: ADVSTORESHELL
related.Description: Most of the strings in ADVSTORESHELL are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed. API function names are also reversed, presumably to avoid detection in memory.[14][15]

related.Name: Agent Tesla
related.Description: Agent Tesla obfuscates its code in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.[47]

related.Name: APT18
related.Description: APT18 obfuscates strings in the payload.[140]

related.Name: APT19
related.Description: APT19 used Base64 to obfuscate commands and the payload.[179]

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: APT28 encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm. APT28 has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.[15][169][170][77][171]

related.Name: APT29
related.Description: APT29 uses PowerShell to use Base64 for obfuscation.[174]

related.Name: APT3
related.Description: APT3 obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.[168]

related.Name: APT32
related.Description: APT32 uses the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell and also performs other code obfuscation. APT32 has also encoded payloads using Base64 and a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC). APT32 also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.[143][26][144][145][104][146][147]

related.Name: APT33
related.Description: APT33 has used base64 to encode payloads.[180]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 sends images to users that are embedded with shellcode. The group also obfuscates strings and payloads, including through the use of steganography.[148][149]

related.Name: Astaroth
related.Description: Astaroth obfuscates its JScript code.[112]

related.Name: AuditCred
related.Description: AuditCred encrypts the configuration.[89]

related.Name: Bisonal
related.Description: Bisonal's DLL file and non-malicious decoy file are encrypted with RC4.[94]

related.Name: BlackOasis
related.Description: BlackOasis's first stage shellcode contains a NOP sled with alternative instructions that was likely designed to bypass antivirus tools.[134]

related.Name: BOOSTWRITE
related.Description: BOOSTWRITE has encoded its payloads using a ChaCha stream cipher with a 256-bit key and 64-bit Initialization vector (IV) to evade detection.[132]

related.Name: Carbanak
related.Description: Carbanak encrypts strings to make analysis more difficult.[29]

related.Name: Carbon
related.Description: Carbon encrypts configuration files and tasks for the malware to complete using CAST-128 algorithm.[73]

related.Name: Cardinal RAT
related.Description: Cardinal RAT encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted (AES-128) when downloaded. [57]

related.Name: Cobalt Group
related.Description: Cobalt Group obfuscated several scriptlets and code used on the victim’s machine, including through use of XOR and RC4.[141][142]

related.Name: CoinTicker
related.Description: CoinTicker initially downloads a hidden encoded file.[115]

related.Name: Comnie
related.Description: Comnie uses RC4 and Base64 to obfuscate strings.[78]

related.Name: CORESHELL
related.Description: CORESHELL obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.[24]

related.Name: CozyCar
related.Description: The payload of CozyCar is encrypted with simple XOR with a rotating key. The CozyCar configuration file has been encrypted with RC4 keys.[100]

related.Name: Dark Caracal
related.Description: Dark Caracal has obfuscated strings in Bandook by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.[177]

related.Name: Darkhotel
related.Description: Darkhotel has obfuscated code used in an operation using RC4 and other methods.[163]

related.Name: Daserf
related.Description: Daserf uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.[95]

related.Name: Denis
related.Description: Denis obfuscates its code and encrypts the API names. Denis also encodes its payload in Base64.[103][104]

related.Name: DOGCALL
related.Description: DOGCALL is encrypted using single-byte XOR.[72]

related.Name: Dust Storm
related.Description: Dust Storm has encoded payloads with a single-byte XOR, both skipping the key itself and zeroing in an attempt to avoid exposing the key.[135]

related.Name: DustySky
related.Description: The DustySky dropper uses a function to obfuscate the name of functions and other parts of the malware.[31]

related.Name: Ebury
related.Description: Ebury has obfuscated its strings with a simple XOR encryption with a static key.[116]

related.Name: Elderwood
related.Description: Elderwood has encrypted documents and malicious executables.[43]

related.Name: Elise
related.Description: Elise encrypts several of its files, including configuration files.[58]

related.Name: Emissary
related.Description: Variants of Emissary encrypt payloads using various XOR ciphers, as well as a custom algorithm that uses the "srand" and "rand" functions.[36][37]

related.Name: Emotet
related.Description: Emotet has obfuscated macros within malicious documents to hide the URLs hosting the malware,  CMD.exe arguments, and PowerShell scripts.[106][107][108][109]

related.Name: Empire
related.Description: Empire has the ability to obfuscate commands using Invoke-Obfuscation.[13]

related.Name: Epic
related.Description: Epic heavily obfuscates its code to make analysis more difficult.[102]

related.Name: Exaramel for Linux
related.Description: Exaramel for Linux uses RC4 for encrypting the configuration.[129]

related.Name: FELIXROOT
related.Description: FELIXROOT encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.[27][28]

related.Name: FIN7
related.Description: FIN7 has used fragmented strings, environment variables, standard input (stdin), and native character-replacement functionalities to obfuscate commands.[4][178]

related.Name: FIN8
related.Description: FIN8 has used environment variables and standard input (stdin) to obfuscate command-line arguments. FIN8 also obfuscates malicious macros delivered as payloads.[4][133]

related.Name: Final1stspy
related.Description: Final1stspy obfuscates strings with base64 encoding.[72]

related.Name: FinFisher
related.Description: FinFisher is heavily obfuscated in many ways, including through the use of spaghetti code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs. It also uses a custom XOR algorithm to obfuscate code.[17][18]

related.Name: FlawedGrace
related.Description: FlawedGrace encrypts its C2 configuration files with AES in CBC mode.[118]

related.Name: FruitFly
related.Description: FruitFly executes and stores obfuscated Perl scripts.[85]

related.Name: Fysbis
related.Description: Fysbis has been encrypted using XOR and RC4. [130]

related.Name: Gallmaker
related.Description: Gallmaker obfuscated shellcode used during execution.[172]

related.Name: Gazer
related.Description: Gazer logs its actions into files that are encrypted with 3DES. It also uses RSA to encrypt resources.[49]

related.Name: GravityRAT
related.Description: GravityRAT supports file encryption (AES with the key "lolomycin2017").[101]

related.Name: GreyEnergy
related.Description: GreyEnergy encrypts its configuration files with AES-256 and also encrypts its strings.[28]

related.Name: Group5
related.Description: Group5 disguised its malicious binaries with several layers of obfuscation, including encrypting the files.[157]

related.Name: H1N1
related.Description: H1N1 uses multiple techniques to obfuscate strings, including XOR.[79]

related.Name: HAWKBALL
related.Description: HAWKBALL has encrypted the payload with an XOR-based algorithm.[125]

related.Name: Helminth
related.Description: The Helminth config file is encrypted with RC4.[16]

related.Name: Hi-Zor
related.Description: Hi-Zor uses various XOR techniques to obfuscate its components.[46]

related.Name: HiddenWasp
related.Description: HiddenWasp encrypts its configuration and payload.[127]

related.Name: HOMEFRY
related.Description: Some strings in HOMEFRY are obfuscated with XOR x56.[19]

related.Name: Honeybee
related.Description: Honeybee drops files with base64-encoded data.[159]

related.Name: HTTPBrowser
related.Description: HTTPBrowser's code may be obfuscated through structured exception handling and return-oriented programming.[50]

related.Name: Hydraq
related.Description: Hydraq uses basic obfuscation in the form of spaghetti code.[43][44]

related.Name: InnaputRAT
related.Description: InnaputRAT uses an 8-byte XOR key to obfuscate API names and other strings contained in the payload.[23]

related.Name: InvisiMole
related.Description: InvisiMole avoids analysis by encrypting all strings, internal files, configuration data.[32]

related.Name: Invoke-PSImage
related.Description: Invoke-PSImage can be used to embed a PowerShell script within the pixels of a PNG file.[11]

related.Name: ISMInjector
related.Description: ISMInjector is obfuscated with the off-the-shelf SmartAssembly .NET obfuscator created by red-gate.com.[35]

related.Name: JHUHUGIT
related.Description: Many strings in JHUHUGIT are obfuscated with a XOR algorithm.[75][76][77]

related.Name: JPIN
related.Description: A JPIN uses a encrypted and compressed payload that is disguised as a bitmap within the resource section of the installer.[71]

related.Name: jRAT
related.Description: jRAT’s Java payload is encrypted with AES. Additionally, backdoor files are encrypted using DES as a stream cipher. Later variants of jRAT also incorporated AV evasion methods such as Java bytecode obfuscation via the commercial Allatori obfuscation tool.[60][61]

related.Name: Kazuar
related.Description: Kazuar is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector. Kazuar also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.[20]

related.Name: KeyBoy
related.Description: In one version of KeyBoy, string obfuscation routines were used to hide many of the critical values referenced in the malware.[122]

related.Name: Kwampirs
related.Description: Kwampirs downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.[45]

related.Name: Lazarus Group
related.Description: Lazarus Group malware uses multiple types of encryption and encoding in its malware files, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, basic XOR with constant 0xA7, and other techniques.[150][151][152][153]

related.Name: Leafminer
related.Description: Leafminer obfuscated scripts that were used on victim machines.[139]

related.Name: Leviathan
related.Description: Leviathan has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.[74]

related.Name: LightNeuron
related.Description: LightNeuron encrypts its configuration files with AES-256.[128]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete has used pyobfuscate, zlib compression, and base64 encoding for obfuscation.[131]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete employed some visual obfuscation techniques by naming variables as combinations of letters to hinder analysis.[186]

related.Name: Magic Hound
related.Description: Magic Hound malware has used base64-encoded commands and files, and has also encrypted embedded strings with AES.[158]

related.Name: Matroyshka
related.Description: Matroyshka obfuscates API function names using a substitute cipher combined with Base64 encoding.[42]

related.Name: menuPass
related.Description: menuPass has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.[136][137]

related.Name: Micropsia
related.Description: Micropsia obfuscates the configuration with a custom Base64 and XOR.[54][55]

related.Name: Mosquito
related.Description: Mosquito’s installer is obfuscated with a custom crypter to obfuscate the installer.[48]

related.Name: MuddyWater
related.Description: MuddyWater has used Daniel Bohannon’s Invoke-Obfuscation framework. The group has also used other obfuscation methods, including Base64 obfuscation of VBScripts and PowerShell commands.[160][26][160][40][161][162]

related.Name: NanHaiShu
related.Description: NanHaiShu encodes files in Base64.[64]

related.Name: NanoCore
related.Description: NanoCore’s plugins were obfuscated with Eazfuscater.NET 3.3.[91]

related.Name: Night Dragon
related.Description: A Night Dragon DLL included an XOR-encoded section.[176]

related.Name: NOKKI
related.Description: NOKKI uses Base64 encoding for strings.[56]

related.Name: OilRig
related.Description: OilRig has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.[164][88][165][166][167]

related.Name: OLDBAIT
related.Description: OLDBAIT obfuscates internal strings and unpacks them at startup.[24]

related.Name: OopsIE
related.Description: OopsIE uses the Confuser protector to obfuscate an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2. OopsIE also encodes collected data in hexadecimal format before writing to files on disk and obfuscates strings.[96][97]

related.Name: Orz
related.Description: Some Orz strings are base64 encoded, such as the embedded DLL known as MockDll.[74]

related.Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
related.Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D encrypts its strings in RSA256 and encodes them in a custom base64 scheme and XOR.[93]

related.Name: Patchwork
related.Description: Patchwork has obfuscated a script with Crypto Obfuscator.[138]

related.Name: Pisloader
related.Description: Pisloader obfuscates files by splitting strings into smaller sub-strings and including "garbage" strings that are never used. The malware also uses return-oriented programming (ROP) technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.[90]

related.Name: PoisonIvy
related.Description: PoisonIvy hides any strings related to its own indicators of compromise.[83]

related.Name: POSHSPY
related.Description: POSHSPY appends a file signature header (randomly selected from six file types) to encrypted data prior to upload or download.[67]

related.Name: PowerDuke
related.Description: PowerDuke uses steganography to hide backdoors in PNG files, which are also encrypted using the Tiny Encryption Algorithm (TEA).[1]

related.Name: PowerSploit
related.Description: PowerSploit contains a collection of ScriptModification modules that compress and encode scripts and payloads.[9][10]

related.Name: PowerStallion
related.Description: PowerStallion uses a XOR cipher to encrypt command output written to its OneDrive C2 server.[126]

related.Name: POWERSTATS
related.Description: POWERSTATS uses character replacement, PowerShell environment variables, and XOR encoding to obfuscate code. POWERSTATS's backdoor code is a multi-layer obfuscated, encoded, and compressed blob.[40][41]

related.Name: Prikormka
related.Description: Some resources in Prikormka are encrypted with a simple XOR operation or encoded with Base64.[38]

related.Name: PUNCHBUGGY
related.Description: PUNCHBUGGY has hashed most its code's functions and encrypted payloads with base64 and XOR.[121]

related.Name: PUNCHTRACK
related.Description: PUNCHTRACK is loaded and executed by a highly obfuscated launcher.[84]

related.Name: Putter Panda
related.Description: Droppers used by Putter Panda use RC4 or a 16-byte XOR key consisting of the bytes 0xA0 – 0xAF to obfuscate payloads.[175]

related.Name: QUADAGENT
related.Description: QUADAGENT was likely obfuscated using Invoke-Obfuscation.[88][26]

related.Name: Reaver
related.Description: Reaver encrypts some of its files with XOR.[22]

related.Name: RedLeaves
related.Description: A RedLeaves configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.[92]

related.Name: Remcos
related.Description: Remcos uses RC4 and base64 to obfuscate data, including Registry entries and file paths.[12]

related.Name: Remexi
related.Description: Remexi obfuscates its configuration data with XOR.[114]

related.Name: Remsec
related.Description: Some data in Remsec is encrypted using RC5 in CBC mode, AES-CBC with a hardcoded key, RC4, or Salsa20. Some data is also base64-encoded.[65][66]

related.Name: RogueRobin
related.Description: The PowerShell script with the RogueRobin payload was obfuscated using the COMPRESS technique in Invoke-Obfuscation.[25][26]

related.Name: RTM
related.Description: RTM strings, network data, configuration, and modules are encrypted with a modified RC4 algorithm.[30]

related.Name: Sakula
related.Description: Sakula uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.[51]

related.Name: SamSam
related.Description: SamSam has been seen using AES or DES to encrypt payloads and payload components.[110][111]

related.Name: Seasalt
related.Description: Seasalt obfuscates configuration data.[39]

related.Name: Shamoon
related.Description: Shamoon contains base64-encoded strings.[82]

related.Name: SHOTPUT
related.Description: SHOTPUT is obscured using XOR encoding and appended to a valid GIF file.[33][34]

related.Name: Silence
related.Description: Silence has used environment variable string substitution for obfuscation.[181]

related.Name: Smoke Loader
related.Description: Smoke Loader uses a simple one-byte XOR method to obfuscate values in the malware.[98][99]

related.Name: Soft Cell
related.Description: Soft Cell used a modified version of HTRAN in which they obfuscated strings such as debug messages in an apparent attempt to evade detection.[185]

related.Name: SpeakUp
related.Description: SpeakUp encodes its second-stage payload with Base64.[113]

related.Name: SQLRat
related.Description: SQLRat has used a character insertion obfuscation technique, making the script appear to contain Chinese characters.[124]

related.Name: StoneDrill
related.Description: StoneDrill has obfuscated its module with an alphabet-based table or XOR encryption.[117]

related.Name: StreamEx
related.Description: StreamEx obfuscates some commands by using statically programmed fragments of strings when starting a DLL. It also uses a one-byte xor against 0x91 to encode configuration data.[86]

related.Name: SynAck
related.Description: SynAck payloads are obfuscated prior to compilation to inhibit analysis and/or reverse engineering.[62][63]

related.Name: TA505
related.Description: TA505 has password-protected malicious Word documents and used base64 encoded PowerShell commands.[182][183][184]

related.Name: Threat Group-3390
related.Description: A Threat Group-3390 tool can encrypt payloads using XOR. Threat Group-3390 malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.[154][155][156]

related.Name: TINYTYPHON
related.Description: TINYTYPHON has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.[80]

related.Name: TrickBot
related.Description: TrickBot uses non-descriptive names to hide functionality and uses an AES CBC (256 bits) encryption algorithm for its loader and configuration files.[59]

related.Name: Tropic Trooper
related.Description: Tropic Trooper has encrypted configuration files.[173]

related.Name: Turla
related.Description: Turla has used encryption (including salted 3DES via PowerSploit's Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.[126]

related.Name: TYPEFRAME
related.Description: APIs and strings in some TYPEFRAME variants are RC4 encrypted. Another variant is encoded with XOR.[81]

related.Name: UBoatRAT
related.Description: UBoatRAT encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.[69]

related.Name: Ursnif
related.Description: Ursnif has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.   Ursnif droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded PowerShell commands.[119][120]

related.Name: USBStealer
related.Description: Most strings in USBStealer are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.[21]

related.Name: VERMIN
related.Description: VERMIN is obfuscated using the obfuscation tool called ConfuserEx.[105]

related.Name: Volgmer
related.Description: A Volgmer variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.[70]

related.Name: XTunnel
related.Description: A version of XTunnel introduced in July 2015 obfuscated the binary using opaque predicates and other techniques in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.[68]

related.Name: Yahoyah
related.Description: Yahoyah encrypts its configuration file using a simple algorithm.[123]

related.Name: ZeroT
related.Description: ZeroT has encrypted its payload with RC4.[87]

related.Name: Zeus Panda
related.Description: Zeus Panda encrypts strings with XOR and obfuscates the macro code from the initial payload. Zeus Panda also encrypts all configuration and settings in AES and RC4.[52][53]
Consider utilizing the Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) on Windows 10 to analyze commands after being processed/interpreted.
